author: David Penrose
title: Lockleys backyard pool cost the owner $55,000 more than it needed to |
text:
A DECISION to flout local planning laws has left one Adelaide man’s wallet $55,000 lighter: he failed to seek approval before building a backyard swimming pool.
The Lockleys resident has been ordered to pay almost $55,000 in fines and legal bills for building a pool and extensions on his property without West Torrens Council’s consent.
Leonidis George Flourentzou this month pleaded guilty to undertaking development without approval and failing to comply with a notice requiring him to stop work.
The work was completed on three subdivided properties on Strathmore and Rutland avenues.
The Environment, Resources and Development court ordered Mr Flourentzou to pay a $34,200 fine, reduced from $57,000 following an early plea, plus the council’s $20,000 legal costs.
The court heard the unauthorised work had continued over an extended period of time, despite an enforcement notice from the council requesting work be stopped.
Court documents showed Mr Flourentzou had been handed a notice to stop a previous development in 2001 and would have been aware of the need to gain approval.
The court heard the latest developments would likely have gained retrospective approval.
Development consent has since been granted for the work subject to a boundary realignment of the properties.
Mr Flourentzou declined to comment when contacted by the Weekly Times Messenger .
